thread.title: Uber says less than 10% of Calif. drivers can join employment class-action
thread.title_full: Uber says less than 10% of Calif. drivers can join employment class-action

title: Uber says less than 10% of Calif. drivers can join employment class-action
text:
In this July 15, 2015 file photo, Uber driver Karim Amrani sits in his car parked near the San Francisco International Airport parking area in San Francisco. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, File) ORG XMIT: NYBZ118 (Photo: Jeff Chiu, AP)
4 CONNECT 14 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE NEW YORK — Uber Technologies estimated that less than 10% of its 160,000 California driving base will be eligible to join a class-action lawsuit that threatens the ride-hailing app makers' business model by demanding Uber treat drivers as employees.
On Tuesday, a handful of drivers were granted class-action status in the lawsuit, raising the stakes for Uber if the drivers win their case. The drivers — Thomas Colopy, Matthew Manahan and Elie Gurfinkel — are suing Uber on the grounds that they should be labeled employees and not independent contractors, an issue that goes to the heart of how Uber does business as a win by the drivers could increase costs for the $51 billion company.
The judge in the case, U.S. District Judge Edward Chen, put limits on the class in his ruling Tuesday. For example, Judge Chen said the drivers can only sue on behalf of UberBlack, UberX, and UberSUV drivers who have driven for Uber in the state of California at any time since Aug. 16, 2009. To join the class, drivers also must have signed up to drive directly with Uber or an Uber subsidiary, among other restrictions.
Uber said its "early estimates" suggest that fewer than 15,000 drivers will therefore be eligible to join the class-action lawsuit. Uber also said that one of the three plaintiffs, Colopy, will be disqualified because he drove for Uber as an employee of limo companies.
USA TODAY
Uber's California drivers granted class-action status - upping financial stakes
The San Francisco start-up keeps expenses down by positioning itself as a technology company that merely matches drivers with riders, rather a taxi or car service company with vehicles to maintain. That means Uber's drivers are saddled with expenses such as maintenance, insurance, gas and the vehicles themselves.
If Uber is forced to treat drivers as employees, it could be forced to bear some of those costs as well as Social Security, workers compensation and other benefits.
Uber will appeal the ruling, it said.
Follow USA TODAY reporter Kaja Whitehouse on Twitter: @kajawhitehouse.
